Abstract: Gas-phase computational spectroscopy has emerged as a pivotal tool in deciphering the complex behaviors of the molecular bricks of life, offering unparalleled insights into their structural and dynamic properties. This study delves into the challenges and advancements in accurately predicting rotational and vibrational spectra of these fundamental molecules, which are crucial for understanding their roles in biological processes. The inherent flexibility and anharmonicity of these molecules pose significant hurdles in computational modeling, necessitating sophisticated approaches to capture their true nature. By leveraging state-of-the-art computational techniques, this research aims to bridge the gap between theoretical predictions and experimental observations, enhancing our comprehension of the molecular bricks of life. The findings underscore the importance of computational spectroscopy in unraveling the intricate dance of atoms and molecules that constitute the essence of life, paving the way for novel discoveries in biochemistry and molecular biology.
